metadata.description: Provides background knowledge and calculation rules for income segregation reasoning

income_segregation_definition.definition: Income segregation refers to the degree to which individuals with different income levels are spatially separated within a geographic area. One visible and consequential manifestation is socioeconomic segregation - the spatial and social separation of income groups that limits inter-class contact, entrenches mobility barriers, and distorts perceptions of inequality. Recent work has shifted attention to exposure segregation, the degree to which daily encounters cross income groups, moving beyond static, residence-based measures to the dynamics shaped by complex mobility patterns and heterogeneous urban form.
income_segregation_definition.measurement_approach: Measured by analyzing the proportion of different income groups among visitors to each Census Tract and calculating the deviation from an equal distribution. This captures exposure segregation based on daily mobility patterns rather than residential segregation.
income_segregation_definition.key_distinction: This analysis focuses on the income composition of people VISITING the Census Tract, not just those residing there, reflecting real-world exposure and interaction patterns.

income_groups_definition.definition_method: Income groups are defined by ranking the search population's income within each city and dividing into four equal quartiles
income_groups_definition.low_income_p1: Bottom 25% of income distribution among visitors to the city
income_groups_definition.lower_middle_income_p2: 25-50% of income distribution among visitors to the city
income_groups_definition.upper_middle_income_p3: 50-75% of income distribution among visitors to the city
income_groups_definition.high_income_p4: Top 25% of income distribution among visitors to the city
income_groups_definition.note: These are relative rankings based on the income distribution of people visiting the area, reflecting exposure segregation patterns

variables.p_i: Proportion of visiting income group i in the tract (P1, P2, P3, P4)
variables.0.25: Expected proportion under perfect income distribution among visitors (4 equal groups)

calculation_steps: Calculate absolute difference for each visitor group: |p_i - 0.25|

interpretation.0.0-0.2: Low exposure segregation - relatively equal income distribution among visitors
interpretation.0.2-0.4: Moderate exposure segregation - some income clustering among visitors
interpretation.0.4-0.6: High exposure segregation - significant income separation among visitors
interpretation.0.6-1.0: Very high exposure segregation - extreme income concentration among visitors

segregation_index_formula.context_note: This measures how much daily encounters in this tract cross income boundaries, reflecting real-world social exposure patterns

step_1_summary.description: Provide overall context and objective of the analysis with emphasis on exposure segregation
required_content: State the goal: estimating income exposure segregation level within the Census Tract
Mention data sources: street view and remote sensing images
Explain the approach: analyzing visual elements to infer income composition of VISITORS
Reference the exposure segregation index calculation based on visitor patterns
Emphasize this measures daily encounters across income groups, not just residential patterns

step_2_caption.description: Analyze and describe visual elements from both image types to infer visitor income patterns

remote_sensing_analysis.reporting_format: For each element, report: 'X image(s) show ElementName'
remote_sensing_analysis.interpretation_note: These elements help infer the income composition of people who visit or are associated with this location

street_view_analysis.reporting_format: For each element, report: 'X image(s) show ElementName'
street_view_analysis.interpretation_note: Street-level features help estimate the income diversity of people visiting or passing through this area

income_estimation.purpose: Based on visual observations, estimate income group proportions of VISITORS to the tract
income_estimation.required_output: Four proportions: P1, P2, P3, P4 that sum to 1.0
income_estimation.context: These proportions represent the estimated income distribution among people associated with this location through visits or daily activities

step_3_calculation.description: Calculate exposure segregation index using the formula based on visitor income patterns
required_content: State the exposure segregation formula: S = (2/3) * Σ |p_i - 0.25|
Show substitution with estimated visitor income values
Calculate intermediate values: |p_i - 0.25| for each visitor group
Present the exposure segregation score with 2 decimal places

step_4_answer.description: Present final results in structured format emphasizing visitor-based segregation
formatting_requirements: List income proportions with group labels
Show exposure segregation index with label
Note: proportions represent estimated income distribution among visitors

data_validation.proportion_sum: P1 + P2 + P3 + P4 must equal 1.0
data_validation.proportion_range: Each p_i must be between 0 and 1

template_completeness.visual_elements_reporting: All identified elements must be reported with counts
template_completeness.calculation_transparency: All intermediate steps must be shown
